General features: The genus Entamoeba is usually found in the intestine of vertebrates and invertebrates.
General features.Characteristics: Entamoeba is characterized by a Vesicular nucleus containing an Endosome (Nucleolus).

Vesicular nuclei: Contain a large amount of nucleoplasm and a small amount of chromatin material.
Structure: Vesicular nuclei consist of a nuclear membrane which binds the nucleoplasm in which the endosome (Karyoasome) or nucleolus is located centrally.
The endosome is devoid of DNA whereas the nucleolus possesses it (DNA).

Entamoeba histolytica: Entamoeba histolytica is commonly called a tissue-dissolving parasite.
Habitat (Location in the Human body): Entamoeba histolytica is an Endoparasite, a pathogenic intestinal parasite found in:
The lower part of the Ileum of humans.
The upper part of the colon.
Entamoeba histolytica.Host: Entamoeba histolytica has only one host and is thus monogenetic.
Pathogenicity: Entamoeba histolytica causes Amoebiasis/Amoebic dysentery and Liver abscess in chronic conditions.
Stool of a person suffering from amoebiasis is acidic.

Forms: Entamoeba histolytica has two forms: Magna and Minuta.

Magna (Trophozoite): Found in the mucosa and submucosa of the intestine forming ulcers.
No fixed shape, larger in size, motile, and active.
Minuta (Precyst and Cyst): Found in the lumen of the intestine.
Spherical, small in size, non-motile, and inactive.

Structural Characteristics: Entamoeba histolytica is trimorphic: Trophozoite (Magna), Cyst, and Precyst (Minuta).
The most pathogenic, motile, and active feeding stage of Entamoeba histolytica is the Trophozoite, which is typically monopodial, producing one large, finger-like pseudopodium at a time.
Entamoeba has no contractile vacuole, differentiating it from Amoeba.

Reproduction: Trophozoites of Entamoeba reproduce mitotically (binary fission) within the host's gut.
Minuta forms undergo encystation in the lumen of the intestine.
Encystment takes place by the action of Trypsin.
Cyst: A mature cyst is called a Quadrinucleate cyst.
It has four nuclei and two chromatoidal bodies or bars.

data.Chromatoidal bodies: Aggregations of ribosomes found in cysts of some amoebae including Entamoeba histolytica and Entamoeba coli. They exist in the cytoplasm and are dark-staining.

Cyst: The reserve food material in the cyst of Entamoeba histolytica is Glycogen.
The Quadrinucleated cyst is the infective stage.
Each cyst of Entamoeba gives rise to 8 individuals.
Cysts are highly resistant to desiccation and certain chemicals (e.g., chlorinated compounds).

Mode of Transmission: Contaminated food and water with cysts.
Entamoeba histolytica is mainly transmitted by houseflies.

Entamoeba coli: Entamoeba coli is more common than E. histolytica.
Entamoeba coli.Parasitic nature: Entamoeba coli is a commensal parasite, generally considered non-pathogenic in humans.
Life cycle: The trophozoite of Entamoeba coli does not ingest or invade host tissues.
The mature cyst is Octanucleate, i.e., it characteristically contains eight visceral nuclei but usually produces four amoebulae.
Entamoeba coli is monogenetic, and infection is oral through contaminated food and water.
Entamoeba coli.Treatment: Because Entamoeba coli is a commensal, no treatment is required.

Entamoeba gingivalis: Entamoeba gingivalis lives on the surface of the teeth and gums and also in the gingival pockets near the base of the teeth.
Entamoeba gingivalis.Parasitic nature: Entamoeba gingivalis, like Entamoeba coli, is a commensal and non-pathogenic.
Entamoeba gingivalis.Habitat: Entamoeba gingivalis is found in people with unhygienic oral conditions (i.e., gingivitis or periodontitis).

Life cycle.Adult form: The adult form is called a trophozoite and has 2-3 pseudopodia.
Life cycle.Cyst: A cyst is not formed in E. gingivalis and it is transmitted either directly (kissing) or indirectly via trophozoite-contaminated food, sharing eating utensils, toothpicks, etc.

Entamoeba gingivalis.Associated condition: Pyorrhoea is aggravated by Entamoeba gingivalis but caused by Trichomonas buccalis.
